child.geography: "Spoken in eastern Libya and in the Siwa Oasis in Egypt

child.pub-comments: Egyptian, like every other language, underwent diachronic changes, and it needs to be appreciated that distinguishing 'varieties' we are thinking about variation over time. Moreover, terms encountered in the literature, such as Old Egyptian (3100-2000BC), Middle Egyptian (2000-1300BC), Late Egyptian, Hieratic, Demotic, Coptic, etc. are often associated with literary and graphical matters rather than linguistic features..." (pg. 78)
child.publications: Hayward, Richard J. 2000. Afroasiatic. In Bernd Heine & Derek Nurse (eds.), African Languages: An Introduction, 1 edn., 75-98. ISBN 0521661781
